About.topicHeading: The International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies
About.body: The International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) is the world’s largest humanitarian network, with 191 National Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies and around 15 million volunteers. Our volunteers are present in communities before, during and after a crisis or disaster. We work in the most hard-to-reach and complex settings in the world, saving lives and promoting human dignity. We support communities to become stronger and more resilient places where people can live safe and healthy lives, and have opportunities to thrive.
About.coverPhotoText:
Bourj el-Barajneh Camp in Lebanon, 10 September 2025.
This people-centred approach reduces barriers of access and hesitancy while upholding dignity, trust and continuity of care in a challenging setting.
Lama Chidiac, IFRC.
About.insidePhotosText: Syrian Arab Red Crescent • Lama Chidiac, IFRC • Aki Kolehmainen, Finnish Red Cross • Syrian Arab Red Crescent • Lama Chidiac, IFRC • IFRC • Paul Wu, IFRC • IFRC and Ecuadorean Red Cross • Pakistan Red Crescent • IFRC

About.copyrightText: Any part of this publication may be cited, copied, translated into other languages or adapted to meet local needs without prior permission from the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies, provided that the source is clearly stated.

meta.title: Acknowledgements and Contributors
meta.description: Recognition of the organizations and individuals who supported the production, translation, and publication of the IFRC World Disasters Report 2026.

Acknowledgements.intro: The <bold>International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies</bold> (IFRC) gratefully acknowledges the support provided by the following organizations for the production and publication of the IFRC World Disasters Report 2026:
Acknowledgements.translation: Translation costs for the Russian and Chinese editions were generously provided by the Academy of the Russian Red Cross and the International Academy of the Red Cross in China.
Acknowledgements.contributions: The World Disasters Report 2026 features over 100 written contributions from more than 60 practitioners and researchers across the humanitarian sector, as well as from governments, academia, civil society and beyond. These contributions appear throughout the report in Contributor Insight boxes, acknowledging the individual authors and their respective organizations.
Acknowledgements.research: The <bold>IFRC Solferino Academy</bold> led a two-month rapid community intelligence study with 40 volunteers and staff from 10 National Societies. Acting as community researchers, they interviewed 132 volunteers and community members affected by humanitarian crises. Findings were synthesised by volunteer academics from the University of Michigan, Northumbria University and Open Lab (Newcastle University), ensuring that local nuance was preserved. Selected quotes appear throughout the report.
